description: From Middle English galoche, from Old French galoche (“shoe with a wooden sole”), but further history is uncertain.

definitionGroups.group: An overshoe or boot worn in wet weather:

entries.meaning: (Britain) A waterproof overshoe used to provide protection from rain or snow.
(US) A waterproof rubber boot, intended to be worn in wet or muddy conditions.
A gaiter, or legging, covering the upper part of the shoe and part of the leg.

verbs.description: galosh (third-person singular simple present galoshes, present participle galoshing, simple past and past participle galoshed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk while wearing, or as if wearing, galoshes; to splash about.
examples: My mother, at the age of seventeen, took them on single-handed, galoshing her way through the mud with bundles of tracts, not necessarily religious but always uplifting, and generous supplies of calves' foot jelly.
